description: Rada Miskovic decides to accept the Council’s offer, agreeing to frame the 'Peace Exchange' campaign as a major opportunity for healing civic divides. She receives exclusive access in exchange for aligning her coverage with the Council’s message.
Rada announces a state media special on the upcoming Peace Exchange, highlighting its potential for creating mutual understanding across district lines and urging public participation.

The Council officially launches the two-week 'Peace Exchange,' mandating each district to adopt and live out the civic value priorities of a contrasting district. Rada’s coverage showcases initial optimism and the Council’s unity narrative.

Frustration and unrest surface as some residents refuse to adapt to the swapped values, with protests in both safety and freedom districts. Rada’s reports downplay the dissent, maintaining the Council’s message of progress.

As the Peace Exchange ends, many citizens resist returning to previous norms, leading to visible rifts within districts. Public debate intensifies over which values should govern going forward, and surface-level calm gives way to deeper polarization.
